properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong winter storm will impact the BC interior with snow beginning this evening. The approaching storm will give widespread snow into the interior this evening. The main band of snow will shift northwards on Friday morning, allowing the snow to come to an end for communities in the Okanagan and South Thompson. Snow will continue in the Kootenays, Columbias, as well as the central and northern interior. In addition there is a chance of freezing rain for the central interior as the band of snow pushes northwards on Friday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T14:14:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T22:15:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2180845932.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on Sunday. Location: Nova Scotia. Timing: All day Sunday into Monday morning. Remarks: A system will approach the Maritimes on the weekend, with the potential for snowfall exceeding 15 cm in some regions. The highest amounts are likely in the northern mainland and Cape Breton. In the south, it is more likely that the snow will be mixed with rain during the morning then will change over to snow later in the day. However, at this time there is significant uncertainty in the specific intensity and exact locations of the heaviest snow. Additionally, strong winds will combine with the fresh snow to create reduced visibilities in blowing snow later in the day and on Sunday night. Accumulating snow, mixed precipitation and blowing snow will make travel difficult on Sunday, motorists are advised to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T01:04:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T09:05:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2935153129.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of severely cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chills of -55 to -65 are forecast to continue today, tonight and throughout the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T01:24:51-00:00

properties.Title: Amber Alert
properties.Summary:
Expires: 2020-01-02T19:45:00-03:30
Originated from CAP Alert: FES-NL, 2020-01-02T19:44:53-03:30, 824A2081-24CA-5E3A-7D24-B503B83737AA
Area: The Royal Newfoundland Constabulary in Corner Brook have issued an Amber Alert for 12 year old Tony Austin “Aussie” GREENHAM who was abducted by his father Tony GREEHAM. Both were last seen on Thursday, January 2, 2020 at 9:45 am. Tony Austin “Aussie” GREENHAM DOB: 2007-09-11 is described as being 5’1” tall, 140 lbs, with brown eyes and brown short hair. Tony GREENHAM is 47 years old, 5’7” tall, 252lbs and has blue eyes, a bald head, and a grey goatee. They are believed to be travelling in a black 2009 Ford Escape NL plate: JEL 275. Anyone with information pertaining to the location of either person or the vehicle is asked to contact police at 709-637-4100, or at 911 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS (8477). You can also provide information anonymously on the NL Crime Stoppers website at www.nl.crimestopppers.com
properties.Author: FES-NL

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific storm will bring snow tonight and Friday. Up to 25 cm of snow is expected by Friday morning. Warm air moving inland will cause the snow to change to rain on Friday. Moderate rain is expected through the day, before it changes back to snow Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:08:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:09:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0288914289.2020
Area: Central Coast - inland sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure centre crossing the North Coast will bring a period of heavy snow to the Stewart region. Snow will begin Friday morning with a few centimetres expected during the day. In the evening, the snow will intensify and 15 cm is expected to fall through the evening and overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T22:42:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T06:43:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2639037689.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to the northern interior tonight through Friday. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening across the Bulkley Valley, McGregor, and Williston regions. Snow will continue through Friday with snowfall amounts of up to 20 to 25 cm by Friday evening. Meanwhile Highway 97 - Pine Pass will see snow beginning tonight with up to 25 cm of snow by Friday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T15:49:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-02T23:50:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3667993096.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District, Williston, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to Fort Nelson and the B.C. Peace Friday. Snow at times heavy will begin Friday morning across the B.C. Peace region then spread North toward Fort Nelson in the afternoon. Snowfall amounts near 10 cm are generally expected. However, the snow will be heavier near the Rockies, including Chetwynd and Hudson Hope, where 20 cm are forecast. Up to 15 cm will fall along the Alaska Highway over higher terrain south of Fort Nelson. Snow should end early Saturday morning for the Peace region and will continue through midday Saturday near Fort Nelson. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T22:39:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T06:40:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2943337489.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River, Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Snow and blowing snow due to strong northeasterly winds of 40 km/h gusting to 60 will continue to bring poor visibilities to Old Crow this morning. Conditions are expected to improve this afternoon as the winds begin to ease and the snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T01:07:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T09:08:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2681291953.2020
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong pacific frontal system will cross Vancouver Island tonight and tomorrow. Rain has already begun over eastern Vancouver Island, and is expected to intensify tonight. Sections of eastern Vancouver Island between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay will see near 50 mm of rain by Friday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-03T16:09:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T00:10:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3828187590.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An approaching Pacific frontal system is giving light rain to the south coast. The rain may be briefly mixed with wet snow this afternoon. Rain will intensify this evening and persist through Friday. During that period, we expect 60 to 80 mm of rain to fall over Howe Sound and Metro Vancouver - central and North Shore. Heavy rain will ease Friday night but light rain or showers will continue into Saturday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow are expected. A strong Pacific storm for tonight and Friday with 30 to 60 cm of snow expected over inland sections of the north coast. Snow will begin this evening for inland sections of the north coast and will intensify tonight. The snow is expected to ease and become mixed with rain Friday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Easterly winds will intensify near the Richardson mountains this afternoon. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson mountains are expected to develop late this afternoon and continue into Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong Pacific storm is impacting the BC coast tonight. Precipitation has begun over Vancouver Island and the Central Coast. The rain will be mixed with wet snow this evening. Rain will persist through Friday. During that period, we expect 100 to 150 mm of rain for the Central Coast - coastal sections, West Vancouver Island and near Port Alice on North Vancouver Island. Heavy rain will ease Friday night but light rain will continue into Saturday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
